Peter,

I believe the challenge in this domain is indeed the fitness functi=
on 
as opposed to the learning method.  The problem is that it is very 
dif=
ficult to describe exactly what should be rewarded early on.  
Rewarding # =
of steps tends to encourage a single flailing step yet 
misses better oscil=
latory behavior.  Even if an individual does learn 
a leg-based oscillation=
, it will likely fall and therefore never be 
noticed.

When Tyler Streeter=
 was working on this problem in his Verve project 
(http://www.vrac.iastate=
.edu/~streeter/verve/gallery.html), which 
used NEAT with leaky-integrator =
neurons, I discussed this problem 
with him often.  I believe he ended up f=
inding a clever way to reward 
oscillatory behavior.  That is the most impo=
rtant thing, since it's 
really the key to walking: it's necessary for the =
circuit to produce 
an oscillating pattern.  I may be remembering wrong, bu=
t I think he 
may have started getting it to work by hanging the biped from=
 an 
invisible "string" from the ceiling, so that it could not fall, and 
s=
imply training it to oscillate its legs.  Have you tried discussing 
it wit=
h Tyler?

By the way, can you please remind me what the inputs and outputs =
are 
on your substrate?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervensk=
i" 
<petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ken, 
> 
> The fitness function us=
ed in the binary is Average_Head_Height * 
> Number_of_FootSteps_Taken. The=
 second multiplier rewards 
individuals 
> that tend to walk around instead=
 of staying still. I know it is 
maybe 
> wrong to assign 0.000 fitness, bu=
t I usually hope that in early 
> generations at least some individuals wil=
l get a score above zero, 
> and therefore survive. Is this a right thing t=
o do or I should 
> translate all fitnesses above 0.000 ? Like Total_Fitnes=
s +=3D 1.0; ? 
> The Number_of_FootSteps_Taken is actually an integer and i=
t makes 
the 
> fitness landscape look like stairs... This is not good, but=
 I can't 
> think of another way to encourage walking around.. Rewarding cy=
clic 
> activity in the output neurons didn't help me much.. It is the same=
 
> thing. 
> 
> I am experimenting with a lot of fitness functions every d=
ay. The 
> best individual I got for the balancing task was actually the sa=
me 
as 
> the one found using regular NEAT - just standing. A way to preven=
t 
> this is may be to choose random initial positions for the model.. 
Or =

> the ground plane can be made moving randomly.. 
> Anyway, it seems that =
the fitness function is wrong, since this way 
> of achieving the goal is t=
oo easy for the evolution to find.
> 
> I am currently trying out how good =
are they to walk. I replaced the 
> Average_Head_Height with Total_Distance=
_Travelled in the fitness 
> function. 
> 
> I believe that HyperNEAT is ab=
le to handle such complex dynamic 
> control tasks, given the right substra=
te geometry. Results so far 
do 
> not show a big progress. But there are a=
 lot of parameters to tweak 
> and play with. Substrate configurations also=
. 
> 
> Ken, what about the source code, can you compile it?  
> 
> Peter
